To solve the problems of small specific surface area and poor thermal stability of CsH3PMo11VO40 (CsPMo11V) catalyst, it was proposed that the organic ammonium precursor polydopamine (PDA) was coated on SiO2 to form PDA-coated SiO2 carrier (SiO2@PDA) and then CsPMo11V was supported to form SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V supported catalyst. In this work, the structure-oriented effect of dopamine layer between carrier and active component on NH4 + distribution was focused on. The performance of the SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V catalyst was evaluated by methacrolein (MAL) oxidation. At the optimum loading of 50 wt%, the conversion of MAL and the selectivity to methacrylic acid (MAA) reached 81.9% and 89.1%, respectively. After continuous evaluation for 120 h, the catalyst exhibited good stability. The reaction kinetic modeling with the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism for the supported catalyst was conducted, which included the oxidation of MAL to MAA on the catalyst and the re-oxidation of the reduced catalyst, and the results suggested that the re-oxidation reaction of the catalyst was the rate-determining step. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidation Methacrolein Heteropoly acid Polydopamine Kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methyl methacrylate (MMA) is an important chemical monomer for the synthesis of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), rubber, ion exchange resin and so on [1–3]. C2 method is a green and efficient method for the synthesis of MMA. Selective oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid (MAA) is an important step in this process. MAL is oxidized to MAA and then esterified with methanol to MMA [4,5]. The main catalyst used for selective oxidation of MAL to MAA is Keggin type P-Mo heteropoly acid catalyst [6–8]. Heteropoly acid catalysts, especially Keggin type heteropoly acids, have high density of acid sites and excellent catalytic performance compared with ordinary inorganic acids such as H2SO4/H3PO4 [9–12]. It is widely used in catalytic oxidation desulfurization of light diesel oil [13], production of biodiesel [14], hydrodeoxidization of 2,5-dimethyl tetrahydrofuran [15] and other fields. In addition, the physical and chemical properties of heteropoly acids can be easily regulated [14], and the acidity and redox properties can be regulated by replacing some atoms in heteropoly anions by other elements [16–18]. However, the general Keggin heteropoly acid has a small specific surface area (usually 3-5 m2·g-1) [19,20], few active sites, poor thermal stability and low catalytic efficiency when used in catalytic reaction [21,22]. In recent years, there have been many reports about supported heteropoly acids to solve these problems. Heteropoly acid was loaded on SiO2, molecular sieve, activated carbon, MOFs and other carriers [23–27]. These methods can effectively utilize the high surface area and high stability of the carrier to improve the performance of the catalyst. Because the oxidation of MAL is co-promoted by acid catalysis and oxygen catalysis [28], oxygen is used in the reaction, and the reaction temperature is generally above 573 K, so the acidity, basicity and thermal stability of the carrier require a certain basis. The carrier needs to have high thermal stability, and the general activated carbon carrier is not suitable for the reaction system. The alkaline or amphoteric carrier will react with the active components of heteropoly acid, causing in the decomposition of heteropoly acid [29], so it is most appropriate to choose weakly acidic or neutral carrier [30]. Even if neutral or weak acidic carriers are used, there are some problems with supported heteropoly acids. First, the heteropoly acid active components will react with some carriers, resulting in the decomposition of the active components. For example, the SiO2 carrier shows weak acidity and good thermal stability, but heteropoly acid can react with SiO2, resulting in the decomposition of Keggin structure [31,32]. Second, the active component is easily lost if there is no interaction between the heteropoly acid and the carrier. This once again limits the scope of carriers. Zhou et al [26]. modified SBA-15 with C3N4 to prevent the reaction between H4PMo11VO40 (HPAV) and the support. Zhu et al.[29] used counterions to regulate the acidity of heteropoly acid, and loaded heteropoly acid on weakly acidic kaolin carrier. Therefore, the stability of the supported catalyst can be improved by modifying the carrier [33] or using counterions to adjust the acidity and basicity of heteropoly acid [34,35]. For the previously reported supported counterion-modified heteropoly acid catalysts, counterions generally exist in the active components of heteropoly acid [29]. Almost all heteropoly acids were modified by counterions first and then loaded on the carrier [36]. It is assumed that the introduction of counterions modifier can not only adjust the acidity and basicity, but also enhance the interaction between the active components and the carrier, so that both catalytic activity and stability can be taken into account. NH4 + is an important counterion for modifying heteropoly acid [37], which can effectively regulate the acidity and redox properties of heteropoly acid [38], and has a wide range of sources and low price [39–42]. Besides, some of the raw materials for forming NH4 + come from organic compounds [43,44], which can well modify the carrier. In our previous study, we found that the introduction of organic amines (polydopamine and polyamide-amine) could regulate the acidity and basicity of the active components [45]. On this basis, if polydopamine is used as the intermediate layer between heteropoly acid and carrier, the activity and stability of the catalyst can be further enhanced by adjusting acidity, basicity. Polydopamine (PDA) is a kind of biomimetic material of mussel, which has good biocompatibility, strong adhesion and high photothermal conversion efficiency [46,47]. The excellent film-forming ability of PDA allows it to be coated on the surface of materials with various properties. Therefore, PDA can be coated on the carrier as an organic ammonia source, and NH4 + can be formed in the calcination process [28]. PDA was coated on the carrier, and then the heteropoly acid was modified. During the calcination process, NH4 + was directionally distributed between the carrier and the heteropoly acid. The structure-oriented function of NH4 + solves the problem of decomposition of the heteropoly acid on the carrier. The supported heteropoly acid catalysts have good industrial application prospects for MAL oxidation. The determination of the kinetic data of the oxidation of MAL to MAA and the discussion of the kinetic law of this reaction have important guiding significance for exploring the catalytic reaction mechanism, selecting reaction conditions and designing the reactor [48]. However, there are few reports on the kinetics of supported heteropoly acids in MAL oxidation. Böhnke et al.[49] and Deusser et al.[48] have reported the kinetic model of MAL oxidation, and the catalysts used in both of them were unsupported heteropoly acid. Therefore, the kinetic behavior of MAL oxidation on supported catalysts needs to be further studied. In this work, PDA was used to modify SiO2 to form a PDA-coated SiO2 carrier (SiO2@PDA), and then loaded with heteropoly acid (CsH3PMo11VO40, abbreviated as: CsPMo11V) to form SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V precursor. During the calcination process, the N-containing groups in PDA were converted into NH4 +. PDA was transformed into NH4 +, and NH4 + was directionally distributed between carriers and active components. The effects of PDA modification on the physical and chemical properties of carriers and heteropoly acids were analyzed by FT-IR/XRD/NH3-TPD/XPS/NMR/TEM/TG/N2-adsorption and desorption. The effects of loading and the amount of PDA on the catalytic performance were investigated. The catalytic activity and long-term evaluation of catalytic stability of the prepared composite catalyst (SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V) for MAL oxidation were studied. Moreover, the oxidation kinetic model of MAL on the supported heteropoly acid catalyst was also established. Hopefully, the results of this work can provide guidance for the industrial application of supported heteropoly acids catalysts in the oxidation of MAL to MAA. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Molybdenum trioxide (≥99.9%), methacrylic acid, vanadium oxide (≥98%), phosphoric acid (≥85%), dopamine hydrochloride (≥98%), tris (hydroxymethyl) amino methane (Tris, ≥99.9%) and cesium hydroxide (≥99%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). SiO2 (surface area: 273 m2·g-1) was purchased in Qingdao, China. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of SiO2@PDA 1.14 g Tris was dissolved in 1000 mL deionized water to obtain Tris buffer solution with pH of 8.5. 6 g SiO2 was dispersed in 500 mL Tris buffer solution, sonicated for 30 min and magnetically stirred for 30 min to obtain uniformly dispersed particles. After that, dopamine hydrochloride was added and stirred for 24 h at room temperature. Finally, the black solid was obtained by filtering and washing with water for three times. After the black solid was dried overnight at 323 K, the SiO2 carrier coated with polydopamine was obtained, which was marked as SiO2@PDA. 2.2.2 Synthesis of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V CsPMo11V was prepared on the basis of reference [28]. A certain amount of SiO2@PDA was dissolved in 50 mL deionized water, stirred for 30 min, and then an appropriate amount of CsPMo11V was added and stirred for 8 h at 353 K. The SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V precursor was obtained by drying at 353 K overnight. Finally, SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V catalyst was obtained by calcination at 623 K for 12 h in air atmosphere, marked as: SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-x, where x represents the loading of CsPMo11V. The contrast catalyst SiO2-CsPMo11V was also synthesized. SiO2 coated with PDA as carrier to support heteropoly acids. NH4 + was formed during calcination and acted as counterions to coordinate with heteropoly acid. PDA acted as a structural guide and promoted the distribution of NH4 +. The formation scheme of the catalyst is shown in Scheme 1 . When dopamine and SiO2 met, the SiO2 carrier coated with PDA (SiO2@PDA) was formed. Then heteropoly acid was added, the SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V precursor was formed, which had a three-layer structure of the precursor, which was SiO2, PDA and CsPMo11V from the inside to the outside. In the next calcination process, the carbon chain in the PDA layer decomposed, in which the N-containing groups were transformed into NH4 +, and coordinated with heteropoly anions. And the PDA interlayer was transformed into NH4 +, so NH4 + was distributed between the carrier and the active components. NH4 +, Cs+, H+ and crystal water molecules were rearranged in the secondary structure of heteropoly acid. Finally, the supported SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V catalyst was formed. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts A series of characterizations were used to analyze the catalysts. The properties of surface groups were analyzed by Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). A Rigaku SmartLab SE diffractometer with the radiation of Cu Kα was used to obtain powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). The textural properties of the carrier and catalyst were characterized by ASAP 2460 instrument. The surface area was calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The thermal stability of the catalyst was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) at NETZSCH TG 209. The temperature rising rate was 10 K·min-1 in air atmosphere. The acid properties of the catalyst were characterized by NH3-TPD on the equipment AutoChem II 2920. About 0.1 g of the catalyst was put into the reaction tube and 60 min was purged in the He flow of 50 mL·min-1 at 393 K, then decreased to 323 K. Then adsorbed the mixture of NH3 and He gas (10% NH3, 15 mL·min-1) at 373 K for 60 min. Finally, the temperature was raised to 873 K under the He gas flow, and the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to detect the signal. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha with monochromatic Al as the X-ray source. The 31P MAS-NMR and 13C MAS-NMR spectra of the catalysts were determined at room temperature using a 600 MHz NMR spectrometer (JEOL JNM ECZ600R). The morphology and elemental distribution of the catalysts were investigated by TEM (TecnaiG2F20, Philips Netherlands Ltd.). Elemental analysis (EA) was carried out on elementar vario Micro cube. 2.4 Performance evaluation of catalyst and kinetic experiment of MAL oxidation The performance evaluation of the catalyst and the kinetic experiment of MAL oxidation were carried out on the basis of the literature [29,49]. The catalyst evaluation equipment was a fixed bed reactor. MAL, H2O and MAA liquid reactants were added by pump, and the gases (O2 and N2) were injected by a mass flowmeter. In the course of the experiment, N2 and O2 were introduced first, and then other reactants were introduced when the temperature reached the preset reaction temperature. The liquid phase reactants were mixed and gasified in the preheater, then entered the reactor, the reactor was connected with the circulating condensation device, and the liquid phase products were collected through the condensation device. After the reaction was stable, the composition of the products was analyzed by Agilent-6820 gas chromatography. The liquid phase products were detected by TCD detector with HP-INNOWAX capillary column. High volatile by-products (such as CO and CO2) were analyzed by HP-PLOT packed column. The experimental equipment in Fig. 1 was basically the same as the equipment used in our previous experiment [29]. 2.5 Kinetic study From Scheme 2 , the oxidation reaction of MAL includes main reaction R1, parallel reaction R2, and continuous reaction R3 [49]. Both R1 and R2 are related to the formation of by-products. MAL is oxidized to MAA, and the resulting product MAA will also be further oxidized into by-products. In addition, MAL can also be directly oxidized into by products, the by-products mainly include CO, CO2, and CH3COOH. At present, it is generally believed that the kinetic study of MAL catalytic oxidation follows the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [49], also known as redox mechanism. The model assumes that the oxidation reaction occurs between the reactants adsorbed on the catalyst surface (MAL or MAA) and the lattice oxygen in the catalyst, which is divided into two reaction steps. First of all, the adsorbed reactants react with the lattice oxygen on the surface of the catalyst, resulting in the reduction of the catalyst and the formation of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst. Then, the reduced active sites on the surface of the catalyst react with O2, the catalyst is re-oxidized, the lattice oxygen is replenished, and the catalyst returns to its pre-reaction state. Among them, lattice oxygen in the catalyst is the main source of active oxygen in MAL oxidation, which has an important influence on the catalytic reaction process. For reaction R1, the specific reaction formula is as follows: MAL + Cat − O → k 1 MAA + Cat Cat + 1 / 2 O 2 → k O 2 , MAL Cat − O Since the oxidation of MAL and the oxidation of MAA occur independently, the MvK mechanism is also suitable for the oxidation of MAA. For reaction R3, the specific reaction formula is as follows: MAL + Cat − O → k 3 by products + Cat Cat + 1 / 2 O 2 → k O 2 , MAA Cat − O The relationship between the oxidation reaction rate and the partial pressure of MAA/MAL/O2/H2O was studied. Table S1 summarizes the experiment. 2.5.1 Establish of the kinetic model The special oxidation state of the catalyst is marked as Ф. For SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-x catalyst, the four characteristic peaks of Keggin heteropoly acid structure at 1064, 965, 870 and 787 cm-1, corresponding to ν αs P-O in the central tetrahedron of PO4, Mo=Od, Mo-Ob-Mo and Mo-Oc-Mo, respectively [50,51]. For CsPMo11V, the four peaks were at 1065 cm-1, 968 cm-1, 868 cm-1 and 776 cm-1. Compared with CsPMo11V, the four Keggin structural characteristic peaks of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-x were slightly shifted. There is a strong hydrogen bond and electrostatic interaction between CsPMo11V (mainly refers to: Cs+/H+/NH4 +) and PDA amino ligands. The heteropoly acid was successfully loaded on the SiO2@PDA carrier and retained the Keggin structure. For compared catalyst SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, where SiO2 serves as the carrier directly, four characteristic peaks of the Keggin structure also appeared. However, different from the catalyst of SiO2@PDA as carrier, the peak for SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst at 1064 cm-1 was weaker than that of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50. This is due to that when SiO2 was not modified by PDA and used as the carrier directly, the Keggin structure was partial decomposed so that the characteristic peak of P-O became weak or even disappeared. The comparison between SiO2 and SiO2@PDA shows the advantages of SiO2 modified by PDA as a carrier. SiO2@PDA as carrier can prevent the decomposition of Keggin structure and improve the stability of the catalyst. It is worth noting that for the catalyst SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V, there was a vibration peak of N-H at 1413 cm-1, corresponding to the characteristic peak of NH4 + [39]. This shows that there was a chemical interaction between PDA and CsPMo11V. NH4 + was formed during the calcination process from N-containing groups in PDA and coordinated with heteropoly anions. NH4 + was a counterion for modifying heteropoly acid, which can improve the catalytic performance of heteropoly acid. The formation of NH4 + from PDA during calcination promoted the uniform distribution of NH4 + between SiO2 and CsPMo11V. NH4 + acted as a “bridge” between carriers and active components, and had the advantage of counterions, which was one of the reasons why the catalyst can maintain stability. In contrast, there was no characteristic peak of NH4 + in the catalyst SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, which was because no raw materials for forming NH4 + were added during the preparation process. In addition, for the carrier SiO2@PDA, the absorption peaks at 1086 cm-1and 808 cm-1 assigned to the asymmetric and symmetrical stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si [52]. All these show that the stability of supported heteropoly acid can be improved by using PDA-modified carriers. The XRD data of SiO2@PDA supports, CsPMo11V active components and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V catalysts with different loading amounts are shown in Fig. 3 . From Fig. 3(A), for the carrier SiO2@PDA, the diffraction peak was nearly amorphous, which was consistent with the peak shape of amorphous SiO2 [53], indicating that the XRD crystal almost no change after SiO2 was coated by PDA. For CsPMo11V active components and three kinds of catalysts (SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-33, SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-67) with different loading amounts, the patterns of XRD diffraction peaks were basically the same. The characteristic peaks at about 10.5°, 26.2°and 35.7°correspond to the (110), (222) and (332) crystal planes of Keggin type heteropoly acids. The diffraction peaks of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V were in good agreement with that of CsPMo11V cubic phase (PDF#46-0481) [54–56]. The difference was that the intensity of the diffraction peak with different loading was different. When the loading increased from 33 wt% to 67 wt%, the intensity of the diffraction peak increased gradually. This change was due to that the characteristic peak of heteropoly acid became more and more obvious as of the content of CsPMo11V increased. Even for the catalyst with only 33 wt% CsPMo11V loading, it has a complete characteristic peak of CsPMo11V. The loading process did not cause the decomposition of the active components of CsPMo11V, and the Keggin structure of heteropoly acid was retained. These results were consistent with that of FT-IR. In order to observe the interaction between CsPMo11V active components and SiO2@PDA carriers during loading, the signal in Fig. 3(A) was amplified. Because the characteristic peak of the (222) crystal plane was the strongest at about 26.2°, the signal in the range of 25.5°to 27° was selected to be amplified, as shown in Fig. 3(B). The position of the characteristic peak on the (222) crystal plane changed before and after loading. For pure component CsPMo11V, the characteristic peaks appeared at 26.30°, while for supported catalysts SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-33, SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-67, the characteristic peak appeared at 26.16°, 26.15°and 26.17°, respectively. This transition to a lower diffraction angle indicates that the d-spacing of the lattice increased [57]. Fig. 4 shows the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of CsPMo11V, SiO2, SiO2@PDA and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50. All the samples had IUPAC IV adsorption isotherms and obvious hysteresis loop [58,59], which indicates that there were mesoporous structures in the supports and heteropoly acid catalysts. The specific surface area and pore structure of the four samples were analyzed, as shown in Table 1 . The pore volumes were 0.02, 1.16, 1.13 and 0.50 cm3·g-1, and the pore sizes were 19.7, 12.8, 13.3 and 13.6 nm for CsPMo11V, SiO2, SiO2@PDA and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, respectively. The specific surface area of SiO2 and SiO2@PDA were 273.5 m2·g-1 and 277.7 m2·g-1 respectively, while for unsupported catalyst CsPMo11V, the specific surface area was only 7.3 m2·g-1. Coating PDA layer on SiO2 surface had no obvious effect on the specific surface area, and the specific surface area of SiO2@PDA was much larger than that of CsPMo11V, therefore, SiO2@PDA can be used as a carrier for loading CsPMo11V. For the catalyst SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, the specific surface area was 138.4 m2·g-1, which was mostly derived from the SiO2 support (50 wt% content). In order to study the thermal stability of the catalyst, thermogravimetric analysis of SiO2@PDA, uncalcined CsPMo11V, uncalcined SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 and uncalcined SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 was carried out, as shown in Fig. 5 . The weight loss of carrier SiO2@PDA mainly came from the physical adsorption of water, dopamine monomers and the decomposition of PDAx [60], For CsPMo11V, SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 precursors, there were two main weight loss stages at below 473 K and 473-723 K respectively. The weight loss below 473 K was the physically adsorbed water on the surface of the catalyst. The weight loss in the range of 473-723 K corresponded to the decomposition of crystalline water in the catalyst and the partial decomposition of the active components [61,62]. The total weight loss of CsPMo11V was about 7.08%. The total weight loss of SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 was about 3.56%, accounting for about half of the weight loss of CsPMo11V, which was very close to the load of 50 wt%. In the second stage, the decomposition temperatures of CsPMo11V and SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 precursors were 553 K and 549 K, respectively. After loading, the decomposition temperature decreased slightly, which was due to the decomposition of Keggin structure and decreased stability. This result was also confirmed by the FT-IR spectra of Fig. 2. For SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, the weight loss in the second stage included not only the decomposition of crystalline water, but also the decomposition of the organic chain of PDA and the partial decomposition of the formed NH4 +. In this stage, the supported heteropoly acid catalyst modified by NH4 + was formed, and the NH4 + was distributed between carrier and CsPMo11V. As a result, the total weight loss of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 was slightly larger than that of SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, about 3.83%. It is worth mentioning that the decomposition temperature of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 in the second stage rised to 613 K, which was much higher than that of CsPMo11V and SiO2-CsPMo11V-50. The increase of decomposition temperature was related to the improvement of the stability of the catalyst [63]. Using PDA modified SiO2 as carrier can improve the thermal stability of the catalyst and effectively avoid the decomposition of active components. Fig. 6 is the NH3-TPD curves of CsPMo11V, SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 in the range of 373 K-873 K. The peak patterns of the three catalysts were very similar, with two wide peaks at 373-573 K and 573-773 K. respectively, corresponding to weak acid region and strong acid region [64,65]. The difference was the intensity and area of the desorption peak. For CsPMo11V, SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, the Tmax values of weak acid region were 488 K, 411 K and 447 K, respectively, and those of strong acid region were 738 K, 740 K and 748 K, respectively. The value of Tmax in the strong acid region of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 was significantly higher than that of CsPMo11V, which indicates that the acid strength of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 was increased. For SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, NH4 + was formed in the process of calcination, NH4 + replaced part of the proton hydrogen in heteropoly acid, improved the fluidity of hydrated protons on heteropoly anions, released acid protons with strong acidity, and improved the degree of protonation. Therefore, SiO2 coated with PDA (SiO2@PDA) as carrier can improve the acid strength of heteropoly acid to some extent. There was NH4 + in SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst, the decomposition of NH4 + had a certain effect on the acidity measured by NH3-TPD, so the acidity mentioned below was the corrected, the correction method of acidity was consistent with the literature [29]. For the catalysts CsPMo11V, SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, the acidity was 0.33, 0.17 and 0.19 mmol·g-1, respectively. The acidity of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 was higher than that of SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, which indicates that the catalyst modified by PDA exposed more acidic sites. Besides, the acidity of the catalyst (SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50) loaded with 50 wt% was more than 50% of the acidity of CsPMo11V. After the heteropoly acid was loading on the carrier, the exposure of acid sites of active components was increased. There was a strong interaction between CsPMo11V and carrier SiO2@PDA, and the Keggin structure of heteropoly acid was retained with high catalytic stability. The increase of acid strength and the exposure of more acid sites can promote the oxidation of MAL. The 31P MAS-NMR spectra of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalysts before and after calcination are shown in Fig. 7 . For uncalcined SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, there were two peaks of P species, and the chemical shifts were at -4.12 ppm and -3.22 ppm, corresponding to the main peak and shoulder peak, respectively. For SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, the intensity of the two peaks changed significantly and the chemical shift values were shifted to -4.44 ppm and -3.68 ppm. The chemical shift values of the catalysts after calcination were shifted towards higher fields as compared to the uncalcined catalysts. The change in peaks before and after calcination was related to the formation of NH4 + in the catalyst during calcination. The stronger signal of the main peak of the catalyst after calcination suggests that the PDA interacted with the Keggin structure in the active component (CsPMo11V) during the calcination process, and the crystallinity of the catalyst was increased. The intensity of the shoulder peak of the catalyst after calcination was lower than that of the catalyst before calcination, this was because the calcination process was accompanied by the loss of crystalline water, so that the electron cloud density around the P atom was higher than that of the catalyst before calcination. This further indicates that there was interaction between PDA and CsPMo11V active components. The catalyst SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 was analyzed by elemental. The content of C element in the catalyst before calcination was 3.28%, and the content of C element in the catalyst after calcination was 0. The content of H element in the catalyst before calcination was 0.71%, and the content of H element in the catalyst after calcination was 0.29%. The content of N element in the catalyst before calcination was 0.63%, and the content of N element in the catalyst after calcination was 0.36%. Compared with the samples before calcination, the contents of three elements C/H/N decreased after calcination, and the carbon chain in PDA decomposed. Both C and N elements in the catalyst SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 originate from polydopamine, so the PDA content decreased slightly after calcination. Based on the content of N element and C element, it was calculated that for the catalyst before calcination, the loading of the active component CsPMo11V-50 was 49.97 wt%, which was basically consistent with the theoretical value of 50 wt%. Fig. S1 is the TEM diagram of SiO2@PDA, uncalcined SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalysts. From Fig. S1(a), PDA was coated on the outer layer of SiO2, indicating that PDA was successfully introduced into the SiO2 support. From Fig. S1(b), compared with SiO2@PDA, there were CsPMo11V species in the uncalcined SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst, and CsPMo11V was distributed on the surface of SiO2@PDA. The measured size of the particles was about 16 nm. EDX Mapping diagrams show that Si, Mo and N elecments were distributed on SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst. The existence of N elements proved that N species were retained in the catalyst after calcination, and the calcination process did not cause the complete disappearance of nitrogen groups in PDA, but some N elements were transformed into NH4 +. And the N, Si and Mo elements in the calcined SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst were clearly observed in the EDX Mapping, which indicated that the supported SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst was successfully synthesized. In order to further prove the effect of the addition of PDA on the valence and composition of elements, XPS characterization was used to analyze the surface element and valence distribution of supported catalysts with or without PDA modification. Fig. 8 shows the N 1s spectra of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst before and after calcination. For the uncalcined catalyst, there was only one peak in the N 1s spectra, which corresponds to the peak of Mo6+ at 398.6 eV. For the calcined catalyst, compared with the uncalcined catalyst, there was an additional peak at 401.6 eV, which belongs to the NH4 + species [66]. The molar ratio of NH4 + to Mo6+ species was 7.3/92.7 (Table 2 ). This change shows that the groups in the SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 precursors evolved during the calcination process, and the N-containing species were transformed into NH4 + species. It is verified with the previous FT-IR characterization. Fig. S2 is the XPS spectra of V species of SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalysts. After deconvolution, both catalysts can be divided into two peaks, corresponding to V5+ and V4+ species at 517.5 eV and 516.5 eV [67]. For the SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst, the molar ratio of V5+/V4+ was 69.9/30.1. For the catalyst modified by PDA (SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50), the molar ratio of V5+/V4+ was 45.1/54.9 (Table 2). The content of V4+ species of the catalyst modified by PDA increased significantly. The main reasons for the formation of V4+ species are as follows: (1) During the calcination process, in the acidic catalyst containing H+ protons, lattice oxygen was oxidized to O2 molecules and disappeared in the environment, resulting in an automatic reduction process [68]. (2) The formation of NH4 + by organic components in SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 precursors also promoted the reduction of V5+ species. The addition of PDA enhanced the automatic reduction process of heteropoly acid catalyst, and there were more electron transfer in heteropoly acid to promote the reduction process of V species. Therefore, the number of V4+ species increased when PDA modified SiO2 was used as carrier. As the active center of MAL oxidation, the increase of V4+ (VO2+) species content contributed to the improvement of catalytic activity [66]. The oxygen atoms in the structure of Keggin type heteropoly acid are mainly divided into the following three types: relatively stable central oxygen Oi (P-Oi), highly active bridging oxygen OB (Mo-Ob-Mo/V, Mo-Oc-Mo/V) and terminal oxygen Od (Mo/V=Od) [44]. The XPS spectra of oxygen species of SiO2-CsPMo11V-50 and SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalysts are shown in Fig. S3, and the distribution of oxygen species is shown in Table 2. For the two kinds of catalysts, they were split into three peaks, and the binding energy position and peak area were different. For SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, the binding energy at about 530.7 eV and 531.7 eV corresponded to Od and OB species. The binding energy at about 532.9 eV corresponded to Oi and Si-O species [60]. Compared with SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, the binding energy of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 decreased slightly, and the binding energies of the three oxygen species were at 530.4 eV, 531.5 eV and 532.5 eV [28]. The content of O species in the two catalysts was also different. For SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, the molar ratio of Od and OB species was 32.9 and 22.5. While for SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50, the molar ratio of Od and OB species was 51.8 and 15.3. Compared with SiO2-CsPMo11V-50, the number of Od species increased in the catalysts modified by PDA. By using PDA modified SiO2 as carrier, the ratio of V4+ species and terminal oxygen Od species was increased, which indicated that the supported catalyst SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 had better redox and catalytic performance. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts Using SiO2@PDA as carrier, the SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 precursor with three-layer structure was prepared. During the calcination process, the N-containing groups in the interlayer of PDA were transformed into NH4 +, and NH4 + was distributed between SiO2 and CsPMo11V. NH4 + acted as a counterion to modify heteropoly acid and can prevent decomposition of active ingredients. The supported catalysts showed good stability and more active sites. Therefore, it is speculated that the supported catalyst had better catalytic performance when it was used in MAL oxidation. In this part, the effects of the amount of PDA and the loading of CsPMo11V on the catalytic performance were investigated, and the long-term evaluation stability of the catalyst was explored. 3.2.1 Influence of the amount of PDA The performance of supported catalysts with different PDA contents is shown in Fig. 9 . The addition of PDA has a certain influence on the oxidation of MAL. When PDA:CsPMo11V = 0, that is, without the addition of PDA, MAL conversion was 65.7% and the selectivity to MAA was 73.9%. With the increase of PDA content, the conversion of MAL increased at first, then decreased, and reached the maximum at PDA:CsPMo11V = 1:1. When the molar ratio of PDA to CsPMo11V was 1:1, the conversion of MAL was 81.9%. With the increase of PDA content, the selectivity to MAA exhibited the same trend as MAL conversion, and also had the maximum value at PDA:CsPMo11V = 1:1. Therefore, PDA:CsPMo11V = 1:1, the amount of PDA added was the most appropriate. There was a certain correlation between the amount of PDA added and the catalytic performance. When the content of PDA was too low, some active components decomposed and the improvement of catalytic activity was not obvious. When the PDA content was too high, the existence of amino, imine and other groups reduced the acidity of heteropoly acid and decreased the catalytic performance. Therefore, the conversion and selectivity increased at first and then decreased, PDA:CsPMo11V = 1:1 was chosen as the suitable amount of PDA. 3.2.2 Influence of the amount of CsPMo11V The catalytic performance of different CsPMo11V loading catalysts (SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-x), and unsupported CsPMo11V catalysts is shown in Fig. 10 . When the loading of CsPMo11V was 20 wt%, 33 wt%, 50 wt% and 67 wt%, the MAL conversion was 51.3%, 74.2%, 81.9% and 77.6%, and the selectivity to MAA was 69.5%, 81.2%, 89.1% and 88.9%, respectively. Both MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA reached the maximum when the loading was 50 wt%. For the unsupported catalyst (CsPMo11V), MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA was 61.5% and 74.2%, respectively. For contrast catalysts (SiO2-CsPMo11V-50), the MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA was 65.7% and 74.2%, respectively. If the loading was too low, there were few active components and active sites in the catalyst, and the oxidation performance of MAL was poor. With the increase of CsPMo11V loading, the catalytic performance increased gradually. However, when the loading was too high, the performance will be very similar to CsPMo11V, and it has the disadvantages of small specific surface area and poor thermal stability. For the catalyst without PDA (SiO2-CsPMo11V-50), the Keggin structure in the active component of the heteropolyacid decomposed and the catalytic performance was poor. Therefore, the catalyst with loading of 50 wt% (SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50) was selected as the suitable catalyst. 3.2.3 The catalytic stability of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 In order to test the stability of the catalyst, the long-term stability evaluation experiment of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst was carried out at 588 K, as shown in Fig. 11 . The MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA remained almost unchanged at 81.9% and 89.1% when the catalyst was used continuously for 120 h. This shows that the stability of the catalyst was good, which was consistent with the characterization results of TG/NH3-TPD/FT-IR. The catalyst exposed more active sites. During the calcination process, the PDA layer in SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 precursor was thermally decomposed. The NH4 + between SiO2 and CsPMo11V was formed, which improved the stability of the catalyst. 3.3 Kinetics study In order to further understand the catalytic oxidation mechanism of MAL on support catalyst, the catalyst (SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50) with high activity and good long-term evaluation stability was selected as the investigation object. Based on the evaluation of the catalyst activity, the kinetic behavior of catalytic oxidation of MAL on the catalyst was studied. Kinetic studies are important for analysing reaction mechanisms, optimising catalyst performance, designing reactors and selecting reaction conditions. The reaction rate obtained from the experiment was fitted by Mars-van-Krevelen (MvK) kinetic model. The reaction rate constants (k) under each reaction were calculated, and the activation energy (E a) and pre-exponential factor (A) of the reaction were calculated by Arrhenius formula. The reaction mechanism on the surface of the catalyst was preliminarily analyzed to provide basis for the improvement and industrial application of the catalyst. 3.3.1 Reaction order and rate constant The reaction order (m, n) and rate constant (k) were solved. The reaction system has both parallel and continuous reactions, and both R1 and R2 consume MAL. MAA was consumed in reaction R3, so reaction R3 can be obtained by oxidation of MAA. First of all, the reaction R3 was solved, then the multiple relationship between r 1 and r 2 was obtained, and then the reactions R2 and R1 were solved. The specific process was described in detail below. In order to solve the reaction rate constant (k 3) and reaction order (m 3, n 3) of reaction R3, the oxidation experiment of MAA was carried out. Fig. 12 shows the oxidation of MAA. The content of each substance entering the reaction system was expressed by partial pressure. The partial pressure was calculated as follows: (n i/n sum) × p. n i represents the molar quantity of a substance entering the reaction system, and n sum represents the molar quantity of all substances entering the reaction system. Because the reaction was carried out at atmospheric pressure, p refers to the standard atmospheric pressure (100 kPa). The substances entered the reactor were MAA/O2/H2O/N2, in which N2 was the carrier gas and the rest were reactants. When the partial pressure of H2O was fixed at 16.5 kPa, the relationship between -r MAA and p MAA was obtained under the condition that the p O2 was 10.8 kPa, 16.2 kPa, 22.5 kPa and 28 kPa, respectively. At each fixed oxygen pressure, the amount of MAA entering the reaction system was varied. The partial pressure of oxygen remained basically constant during the reaction process, so it was necessary to ensure that the partial pressure of oxygen was greater than the partial pressure of MAA. At this point -r MAA = r 3, r 3 was a function about p MAA, r 3 = f (p MAA). Fit the data, and the result was: k 3 = 6.25 × 10-4 (mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1). The data in Fig. S4 were fitted, and k O2,MAA = 1.07 × 10-6 (mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), m 3 = 0.85, n 3 = 0.59, v 3 = -1.70 was obtained. Next, to solve the multiple relationship between r 1 and r 2, the experiment of simultaneous oxidation of MAL and MAA was needed. According to the relation of r MAA = r 1 - r 3, -r MAL = r 1 + r 2, r 1 and r 2 can be obtained, and get the multiple relation between r 1 and r 2, r 1/r 2 = 6.3 (Fig. S5). Fig. 13 shows the oxidation of MAA and MAL. The substances entered the reactor were MAL/MAA/O2/H2O/N2, in which N2 was the carrier gas and the rest were reactants. Fixed p O2 = 16 kPa, p H2O = 18 kPa, the effect of p MAA on -r MAL was investigated. When MAL partial pressure was 2.6 kPa or 5.3 kPa, with the change of p MAA, -r MAL almost did not change, which shows that the addition of MAA had almost no effect on the oxidation rate of MAL reaction. The oxidation experiment of MAL was carried out, and the reaction rate constant (k 1, k 2) and reaction order of R1 and R2 were calculated. Fig. 14 shows the oxidation of MAL. The substances entered the reactor were MAL/O2/H2O/N2, where N2 was the carrier gas and the rest were reactants. When the partial pressure of H2O was 16 kPa, the relationship between -r MAL and p MAL was obtained under the condition that the p O2 was 10.5 kPa, 15.7 kPa, 21.2 kPa and 28.5 kPa, respectively. r MAL was associated with main reaction R1 and the side reaction R2, and r 1/r 2 = 6.3 has been found. r 2 was a function of p MAL, r 2 = (p MAL). After fitting the data: k 2 = 4.13 × 10-5(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), k 1 = 2.60 × 10-4(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1). The data in Fig. S6 were fitted: k O2,MAL = 1.70 × 10-6(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), m 1 = 0.85, n 1 = 0.55, v 2 = -1.999. The obtained data were summarized as follows: k 1 = 2.60 × 10-4(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), k 2 = 4.13 × 10-5(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), k 3 = 6.25 × 10-4(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), k O2,MAL = 1.70 × 10-6(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), k O2,MAA = 1.07 × 10-6(mol·h-1·kgcat -1·pa-1), m 1 = 0.85, m 3 = 0.85, n 1 = 0.55, n 3 = 0.59, v 2 = -1.999, v 3 = -1.70. Similar to the k 1 value reported in the literatures [48,49], it proves the rationality of the kinetic data in this manuscript. The rate constants of the main reaction R1 at different temperatures were calculated, as shown in Table 3 . 3.3.2 Activation energy Fig. 15 was a linear fitting of the experimental data with 1/T as abscissa and lnk as ordinate, and the E a and A was calculated according to the slope and intercept of the straight line, which are listed in Table 4 . The E a of MAL oxidation to MAA step and catalyst re-oxidation step was 99.99 kJ·mol-1 and 154.4 kJ·mol-1, repectively. Therefore, the catalyst re-oxidation step was the rate control step of the reaction R1. The kinetic equation of R1 reaction can be obtained from equation (5) and (8) as follows: r 1 = k 1 p MAL k O 2 , MAL p O 2 n 1 ( 1 + p H 2 O m 1 ) k O 2 , MAL p O 2 n 1 ( 1 + p H 2 O m 1 ) + ( 1 2 − v 2 k 2 ) p MAL k 1 is a function of temperature: k 1 = 1.65 × 102 exp( − 99990 R T ) k O2,MAL is a function of temperature: k O2,MAL = 1.64 × 105 exp( − 154400 R T ) m 1 = 0.85, n 1 = 0.55, v 2 = -1.999 k 1 = 6.3k 2 4 Conclusions SiO2 was coated with polydopamine to prepare SiO2@PDA carrier, and then heteropoly acid was loaded by impregnation-calcination method to obtain a series of SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V supported heteropoly acid. The performance of the composite catalyst in MAL oxidation was investigated. The content of PDA in the carrier had a certain influence on the catalytic performance. When the content of PDA was too low, the active component (CsPMo11V) decomposed, and the catalytic activity was not significantly improved. When the PDA content was too high, the presence of amino and imine groups reduced the acidity of the heteropolyacids and decreased the catalytic performance, and PDA:CsPMo11V = 1:1 was a suitable PDA amount. The effect of CsPMo11V loading on the catalytic performance was studied, and the optimum loading was 50 wt% (corresponding to catalyst SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50). For PDA:CsPMo11V = 1:1, SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V-50 catalyst, the MAL conversion was 81.9% and the selectivity of MAA was 89.1%. The effects of PDA modification on the physical and chemical properties of carriers and heteropoly acids were analyzed by FT-IR/XRD/NH3-TPD/XPS/TG/NMR/N2-adsorption and desorption. With the addition of PDA, NH4 + was formed during the calcination process and directionally distributed between CsPMo11V and SiO2. The SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V catalyst exhibited better thermal stability compared with CsPMo11V and SiO2-CsPMo11V, highlighting the advantages of adding PDA. NH4 + acted as counterions to coordinate with heteropoly acid. The supported catalyst exposed more acid sites and VO2+ active sites, and the catalytic performance was improved. The catalyst showed good stability in the long-term performance evaluation experiment. More importantly, the kinetic model of MAL oxidation on supported heteropoly acid catalyst was established. The E a of MAL oxidation to MAA step and catalyst re-oxidation step was 99.99 and 154.4 kJ·mol-1, respectively. Meanwhile, the results revealed that the re-oxidation of catalyst was the rate-determining step. coredata.dc:description: To solve the problems of small specific surface area and poor thermal stability of CsH3PMo11VO40 (CsPMo11V) catalyst, it was proposed that the organic ammonium precursor polydopamine (PDA) was coated on SiO2 to form PDA-coated SiO2 carrier (SiO2@PDA) and then CsPMo11V was supported to form SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V supported catalyst. In this work, the structure-oriented effect of dopamine layer between carrier and active component on NH4 + distribution was focused on. The performance of the SiO2@PDA-CsPMo11V catalyst was evaluated by methacrolein (MAL) oxidation. At the optimum loading of 50 wt%, the conversion of MAL and the selectivity to methacrylic acid (MAA) reached 81.9% and 89.1%, respectively. After continuous evaluation for 120 h, the catalyst exhibited good stability. The reaction kinetic modeling with the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism for the supported catalyst was conducted, which included the oxidation of MAL to MAA on the catalyst and the re-oxidation of the reduced catalyst, and the results suggested that the re-oxidation reaction of the catalyst was the rate-determining step.
